Posts.Content: People kept telling me how strong I was too and I couldn't understand why they thought that.  I was told I had two Stage 3 tumours, offered a lumpectomy, chemotherapy, radiotherapy then Tamoxifen and of course I said yes to them all.  Of course you're going to choose life!  Someone did explain to me, though, that the side effects of chemotherapy were so horrific (for me anyway, I know everyone's different and don't want to scare anybody) that a weaker person may have been having panic attacks and breathing into a paper bag at the thought of their next cycle of treatment!  Bit extreme, I know, but it kinda made me understand that people saw me as being strong because I faced up to it.  In my view, I had no choice.  I think everyone who faces cancer is unbelievably brave. I've been off work since the beginning of April and hope to return part-time in December - the whole of this month is being taken up with radiotherapy.  Maybe I'm being overly ambitious! It helps reading everyone's postings, would be nice if my boss and everyone else out there maybe read this website now and again!   Joan
Posts.Title: emotional after effects

Posts.Content: Hi Susan I had a lumpectomy for two Stage 3 tumours in March and have just finished chemotherapy.  My oncologist wouldn't allow me to fly - we ended up going over to Ireland by ferry!  Oncologist actually told me that, if it was her, she would be going NOWHERE!  I had quite a fight on my hands, had to promise to do my homework re. where the nearest GP/hospital would be in relation to our hotel, make sure I had my yellow chemotherapy card with me at all times... I had FEC chemo - not sure if it matters what type you have.  Good luck, would be a real shame to miss France.  And maybe your treatment will be over by then, do you know how many sessions you've to have?  I had 6, each one 3 weeks apart. Hope it works out all right for you.   Joan x
Posts.Title: travel insurance

Posts.Content: No wonder you were in pain!  I had an anal fissure years ago, no idea what caused it, but it was agony! And scary when I saw blood in the loo (not nice, sorry!).   Glad you saw your GP and glad you've got cream.  The chemotherapy gave me terrible constipation, I found I couldn't live without lactulose, thankfully it's quite pleasant to take :)   Joan
Posts.Title: A pain in the............!!!!

Posts.Content: Oh yes, most definitely connected to the chemo - like you, I hadn't had "piles" since I was pregnant. I know what you mean about the thought of getting a suppository inside but, honestly, it was surprisingly easy.  Is the cream you have anugesic HC?  Ordinary anusol cream just didn't work for me but when my GP prescribed anugesic HC it made a huge difference.  Check what cream you have and maybe ask your GP for something stronger.  The pain's like toothache, a constant throbbing, I couldn't bear it either.   Joan x
Posts.Title: A pain in the............!!!!

Posts.Content: Oh, most definitely been there, was actually in tears once the pain was so bad.  I had to get my GP come see me one day as I'd had no sleep because of the pain and just felt I couldn't take any more.  She gave me some suppositories, which worked wonders, and after that I bought over-the-counter suppositories, usually anusol.  Even if the haemorrhoids are on the outside, the suppositories really seemed to help.  In addition to the cream! Good luck, I know how awful it can be - I went down to dinner in a hotel one night and had to balance on one cheek for the entire meal - nightmare!   Joan x
Posts.Title: A pain in the............!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Kate I appreciate all you've written, but what sort of side effects do you have?  I'm not even considering not taking the tablets (there's no way I'm going to "invite" a recurrence!), I just wanted to know if anyone had first hand experience.  Am glad you had less radical surgery, too. Thanks and best wishes to you too, Joan
Posts.Title: Any advice?

Posts.Content: Started taking Tamoxifen 5 days ago - have to stay on it for 5 years - anything I've read on Google gives it a bad Press.  I know I have to take it, but has anyone got anything good to say about it?   Still got a month of RT to go through, but getting there!
Posts.Title: Any advice?

Posts.Content: Thanks Colin, Anything that improves survival rates has got to be worth a go.  I've only been taking them for 6 days now so will wait and see what happens. I'm going for my CT scan on Thursday to have the "tattoo" marks so that they know where to localize the treatment, I wouldn't say I'm all that worried about it, but don't doubt that the daily trek to hospital for an entire month will be tiring! Thanks, too, for letting me know there are alternative drugs, hopefully I won't need to switch :)   Joan
Posts.Title: Any advice?

Posts.Content: Thanks Kate, and don't worry about scaring me, I'd rather know than not know, if you see what I mean! I had an early menopause, so have been having hot flushes and night sweats for a couple of years now and, although I hate them, I've gotten used to them.  I don't suppose a few more will make that much difference! Re. the dryness, my boyfriend of 2 1/2 years just dumped me - he couldn't handle the cancer - so I won't be too bothered about that for a while!  When the day does come that I need to,  I'll ask my doctor for some Sylk - will write that name down 'cos I've already learnt that GPs seem to have limited knowledge when it comes to things like hormone drugs. Thanks again - and I have noted that the side effects are only possibilities.   Joan
Posts.Title: Any advice?

Posts.Content: How brave, I had a lumpectomy in April to remove two Stage 3 tumours and thankfully the lymph nodes were clear.  But to go through what you have is incredibly brave, I thought I'd had a hard time.  I found the chemotherapy incredibly difficult and am so glad the 6th one is over - just have to go through a month of radiotherapy in November and I've already started on Tamoxifen. Two operations, now you need a mastectomy and you may have both done?  I take my hat off to you, I honestly do, and I hope everything goes well.   Joan x
